isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Diagnostics Manual - Electronic Control Systems Diagnostics - Circuit Diagnostics - APS/IVS (Accelerator Pedal Position Sensor and Idle Validation Switch)

svcproc.title: APS/IVS (Accelerator Pedal Position Sensor and Idle Validation Switch)

table.title: The Function Diagram for the APS/IVS includes the following:

entry.para: Accelerator Pedal Position Sensor and Idle Validation Switch (APS/IVS)
Amber lamp (Warn Engine Lamp (WEL) for CF)

svcprocinfo.para: FunctionThe APS/IVS sensor is a cab mounted potentiometer sensor. When the APS receives a 5 volt reference signal and a ground from the ECM, a linear analog voltage signal from the sensor will indicate the operator's demand for power. The IVS provides 0 or 12 volts to the ECM as redundant signal to verify the pedal idle position.

svcsubproc.title: APS/IVS Circuit Operation
svcsubproc.para: The APS/IVS are integrated into one component and mounted on the accelerator pedal assembly. The APS/IVS sensor can be replaced without replacing the complete assembly.
The ECM determines the accelerator pedal position by processing input signals from the APS and the IVS.
The accelerator pedal position is one of the controlling variables in the calculation of desired injection control pressure.

APSThe ECM supplies a regulated 5 volt signal from ECM chassis connector Pin X4-4 to APS connector Pin C. The APS returns a variable voltage signal (depending on pedal position) from the APS connector Pin A to ECM Pin X4-18. The APS is grounded at Pin B from the ECM Pin X4-24.

APS Auto-CalibrationThe ECM learns the lowest and highest pedal positions by reading and storing the minimum and maximum voltage levels from the APS. In this manner the ECM auto-calibrates the system to allow maximum pedal sensitivity. The ECM auto-calibrates as ignition switch is on, but when ignition switch is turned OFF, these values are lost. When ignition switch is turned on again, this process starts over. When the pedal is disconnected (or a new one is installed), the pedal does not need to be calibrated. It simply auto-calibrates the new pedal assembly whenever ignition switch is turned on again.
IVSThe ECM expects to receive one of two signals through the ECM chassis connector Pin X4-12 from APS/IVS connector Pin D:

item.para: 0 volts when the pedal is at the idle position.
B+ when the pedal is depressed

svcsubproc.para: The IVS receives a 12 volt ignition voltage at Pin F from the ignition fuse in the power distribution box. When the pedal is not in the idle position (throttle applied), the IVS supplies a 12 volt signal to the ECM.

The ECM compares APS/IVS inputs to verify when the pedal is in the idle position. If the APS signal at Pin X4-18 indicates throttle is being applied, the ECM expects to see 12 volts at the IVS. If the APS signal indicates throttle is not applied, the ECM expects to see 0 volts at the IVS. The timing process is critical between the APS and IVS sensors. For this reason, it is very difficult to determine if the APS/IVS assembly is working correctly when using a DMM.

Fault Detection/ManagementWhen ignition switch is on, the ECM continuously monitors the APS/IVS circuits for expected voltages. It also compares the APS and IVS signals for conflict. If the signals are not what the ECM expects to see, DTCs will be set.

Any detected malfunction of the APS/IVS sensor circuit will illuminate the amber WEL. If the ECM detects an APS signal Out of Range HIGH or LOW, the engine will ignore the APS signal and operate at low idle. If a disagreement in the state of IVS and APS is detected by the ECM and the ECM determines that it is an IVS fault, the ECM will only allow a maximum of 50% APS to be commanded. If the ECM cannot discern if it is an APS or IVS fault, the engine will be allowed to operate at low idle only.
APS/IVS DTCsDTCs are read using the Electronic Service Tool (EST) or by counting the flashes from the amber and red lamps.

note.para: If multiple APS/IVS DTCs are present, verify the APS/IVS part number is correct for the specific vehicle model.
If elevated low idle rpm is experienced after replacing the pedal assembly or APS/IVS sensor, and there are no DTCs present, check pedal assembly or APS/IVS sensor part numbers for correctness.

entry.para: DTC 131 is set if the ECM detects less than 0.147 volts. Possible causes include a short to ground or an open in the APS signal circuit.

DTC 131 can be set due to a short to ground or an open V REF or signal circuits. If the condition causing DTC 131 is intermittent and the condition is no longer present, the code will become inactive and normal engine operation will resume.
When DTC 131 is active the amber lamp (WEL for CF) is illuminated.
DTC 132 is set if the ECM detects greater than 4.55 volts then the ECM restricts engine speed to idle.
DTC 132 can be set due to a short to V REF or B+ in the APS signal circuit.
When DTC 132 is active the amber lamp will be illuminated.
The ECM checks the voltage output of the APS by comparing the APS signal with the IVS signal. APS and IVS signals can disagree in two cases:

item.para: The APS signal indicates the pedal is pressed down to accelerate, but the IVS signal indicates idle position.
The APS signal indicates the pedal has been released to allow the engine to return to idle, but the IVS signal indicates off-idle position of the pedal.

entry.para: If the ECM detects either of the above conditions, the ECM attempts to isolate the source of conflict and set the appropriate DTC.
If the IVS signal is changing and the APS signal is constant, the ECM assumes the APS is the conflict source and sets DTC 133. The engine rpm is restricted to idle.
When DTC 133 is active the amber lamp (WEL for CF) is illuminated.
If neither the APS or IVS is changing, or both are changing, or the ECM cannot determine the DTC in specified time, DTC 134 is set and engine rpm is restricted to idle.
When DTC 134 is active the amber lamp (WEL for CF) is illuminated.

If the APS is changing but IVS is constant, the ECM assumes the IVS is the conflict source and sets DTC 135. In this case the ECM limits the APS signal to a lower value that provides less than full rpm, but does not limit engine rpm to idle.
When DTC 135 is active the amber lamp (WEL for CF) is illuminated.

note.para: DTC 133, 134, and 135 are caused by intermittent conditions. These DTCs remain active until the vehicle has been shutdown and restarted. They do not recover without cycling ignition switch. Later calibration versions may allow DTC recovery without cycling ignition switch.

svcsubproc.para: The APS/IVS circuit requires the use of vehicle circuit diagrams. See applicable truck Circuit Diagram Manual for circuit numbers, connector and fuse locations.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, be careful to avoid rotating parts (belts and fan) and hot engine surfaces.
To avoid personal injury, use care to prevent contact with the door edge when the cab is up and the door is open.

step1.para: Select D_ContinuousMonitor.ssn from the Open Session File window, select Open to open the session.
Select Diagnostics from the menu bar.
Select Key-On Engine-Off Tests from the drop down menu.
From the KOEO Diagnostics menu, select Continuous Monitor and select Run to start the test.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, be careful around rotating parts (belts and fan) and hot engine surfaces.

step1.para: Monitor APS signal voltage. Verify an active DTC for the APS/IVS circuit.
If code is active, do step 8 and 9. Refer to Circuit Checks - APS sensor table.
If code is inactive, wiggle connectors and wires at all suspected problem locations. If circuit continuity is interrupted, the EST will display DTCs related to the condition.
Disconnect chassis harness from APS sensor.

note.para: Inspect connectors for damaged pins, corrosion, or loose pins. Repair if necessary.

step1.para: Connect APS sensor breakout harness to chassis harness only.
When finished with this test, select Session from menu bar, then Close.

Connect chassis harness to sensor. Use the EST to clear DTCs. If an active code remains after checking test conditions, inspect pedal assembly for excessive wear. If pedal assembly is intact, replace the APS/IVS sensor.

entry.para: Use EST, DMM, breakout harness, and 500-ohm resistor harness.
If voltage greater than 0.147 volts, check signal circuit for short to V REF or B+.
Measure voltage from Pin C (BLUE) to ground with DMM
If voltage greater than 5.5 volts, check V REF for short to B+. If voltage is less than 4.5 volts, check V REF for open or short to ground.
500 Ohm resistor harness installed between Pin A (GREEN) and Pin C (BLUE) of breakout harness.

If voltage greater than 4.55 volts, check signal circuit for open or short to ground. Remove negative battery cable. Measure resistance from Pin C to ground (spec > 1 kΩ) to check for short to ground. Use a Breakout Box to measure from Pin A to Pin X4-18 (spec < 5 Ω) to check for open in the harness.
Resistance from Pin B (BLACK) of breakout harness to chassis ground using DMM.
If resistance is greater than 5 Ω, check for open or high resistance between ECM and sensor connector. Use a Breakout Box and measure resistance from between Pin B and Pin X4-24 (spec < 5 Ω)
Turn ignition switch to OFF. Disconnect harness from sensor. Inspect for bent pins or corrosion. Connect breakout harness to chassis harness only. Turn ignition switch to ON.
Voltage greater than 0.25 volts, signal is shorted to V REF or B+
Voltage greater than specification, circuit shorted to B+; Voltage less than specification, circuit open or shorted to ground
Voltage greater than 0.25 volts, IVS signal circuit shorted to V REF or B+
Voltage less than 10.5 volts check circuit for open or high resistance, blown fuse

note.para: See applicable truck Circuit Diagram Manual for fuse location.
